info.name: SN3 API for Demo
info.description: # Overview [StaffingNation](https://staffingnation.com/) is a contingent workforce platform that provides end-to-end HR solutions for global organizations. It offers a suite of features that include full-cycle onboarding, paperless onboarding, KPI dashboard and financial reporting, talent pools, and more. StaffingNation's REST API is designed to provide programmatic access to its platform's functinoality allowing users to authenticate, obtain information about their company, manage contacts, departments, engagements, job descriptions, locations, orders, rates, users, workers, approval processes, and more. The REST API is part of the StaffingNation ecosystem and is intended to provide a seamless integreation between StaffingNation and other software systems used by organizations. # Getting Started Every request to the API includes an HTTP method and a path. Depending on the API endpoint, you might also need to specify a request header, authentication information, query parameter, or body parameter. The API reference documentation describes the HTTP method, path, and parameters for every endpoint. It also displays example requests and responses for each endpoint. For more information, see: [StaffingNation REST API reference documentation](https://d3gfg2aa75v9ki.cloudfront.net/) [Getting started in Postman reference documentation](https://learning.postman.com/docs/getting-started/overview/). # Importing API data from Swagger Postman can import APIs created with the Swagger toolset and any API that follows a supported version of the OpenAPI specification. Perform the following steps to import SN3 Demo API data from Swagger: 1. Launch Postman. 2. Locate "My Workspaces" in the top-left corner of Postman. 3. Click the "Import" button. 4. Paste the URL below into the empty input field and press "Enter" on your keyboard: [https://d3gfg2aa75v9ki.cloudfront.net/swagger.json](https://d3gfg2aa75v9ki.cloudfront.net/swagger.json) Postman documentation available for reference [here](https://learning.postman.com/docs/getting-started/importing-and-exporting/importing-from-swagger/). # Setting up an Environment In Postman, an environment is a set of one or more variables that you can reference when sending requests or writing test scripts. You can create environements for the different types of work/tests you do in Postman. When you switch between environments, all of the variables in your requests and scripts will use the values from the current environment. This is helpful if you need to use different values in your requests depending on the context, for example, if you're sending a request to a test server or a production server. Perform the following steps to setup an Environment in Postman: 1. Navigate to "Environments" located on the left side-panel of Postman, under "Collections." 2. Click the "+" icon to create a new environment. 3. Rename the environment to something appropriate. For example, SN3 Stagging. 4. Create/name the variable in the "Variable" column. For example, base_url. 5. Set the "Type" column to default as we are not passing secret/sensitive data. 6. Leave the "Initial Value" column blank. 7. Set the "Current Value" column to the URL you wish to assign the the base_url variable. For example, if I am testing SN3 stagging, the "Current Value" for the "base_url" variable needs to be set to _"_[https://d3gfg2aa75v9ki.cloudfront.net"](https://d3gfg2aa75v9ki.cloudfront.net)_**.**_ Postman documentation avialable for reference [here](https://learning.postman.com/docs/sending-requests/environments/managing-environments/). # Authorization APIs use authorization to ensure that client requests access data securely. This can involve authenticating the sender of a request and confirming that they have permission to access or manipulate the relevant data. Perform the following steps to request Authorization in Postman for SN3 Demo API: 1. Navigate to Collentions > SN3 API > Authorization > POST Return Authorization Token. 2. Click the _"Send"_ button to generate an authentication token. Postman reference documentation available [here](https://learning.postman.com/docs/sending-requests/authorization/authorization/). # Testing Tests confirm that your API is working as expected, that integrations between services are functioning reliably, and that any changes haven't broken existing functionality. You can write test scripts for your Postman API requests in JavaScript. You can also use test code to aid the debugging process when something goes wrong with your API project. For example, you might write a test to validate your API's error handling by sending a request with incomplete data or wrong parameters. Postman reference documentation available [here](https://learning.postman.com/docs/writing-scripts/test-scripts/#testing-in-postman). # Debugging Tests If you are having trouble with your tests: - Check if there are any errors in your scripts. A red badge will highlight scripts with errors. You can also check the response section for specific errors. - Debug your tests using the [log statements](https://learning.postman.com/docs/sending-requests/troubleshooting-api-requests/#using-log-statements) to ensure that you are asserting on correct data. # Reporting Postman generates reports that enable you to visualize data for how your team uses Postman. These reports give you insights into the state of your APIs, including tests, documentation, and monitoring coverage. They also enable you to track performance and SLA adherence. Access your reports in your [Postman reports dashboard](https://go.postman.co/reports/overview). Postman reference documentation available [here](https://learning.postman.com/docs/reports/reports-overview/). # Interactive API Explorer #### [Experiment with our API directly from documentation!](https://d3gfg2aa75v9ki.cloudfront.net/) # Release Notes **01/29/2024** - Version 1.0 - Kiefer Land - Beta Version **01/31/2024** - Version 1.1 - Kiefer Land (Updated to include sections on the following topics: Importing API calls from Swagger, environemnt/URL best practices, authentication best practices, testing best practices, test failure best pactices, reporting, JSON body data. # References [https://learning.postman.com/docs/](https://learning.postman.com/docs/)
